bow: sleep deprived with week old who takes night shifts in your house any advice if husband doesnt help have beautiful baby boy who just over weeks old my husband works at the office and work from past few weeks and now the sleep deprivation is really getting to me and think it making my ppd worse exclusively pumping so always have bottles prepared for night feeds which thought would be great for co parenting and sharing the responsibility of night feeds however my husband refuses to get up for any night feeds and is now starting to refuse taking the 6am feed before he goes to work which means only getting hours of light sleeping per night not napping during the day when baby naps because working pumping and taking care of the house my husband is now voicing that even though he does get up for night feeds that he not getting enough sleep and is going to bed earlier and is now starting to ask me to take his morning shifts so he can get an extra hour of sleep he can see struggling having breakdown all the time but the only thing he can say is how make him feel guilty if he complains about being tired and having to go to work how do did your household do nights without losing your mind and not killing your husband haha know it going to eventually get better but anything helps in the short term my husband knows how feel very open when it comes to communicating how feel however he says he needs sleep to go to work the next day and he ca do anything about it your husband needs to step up you re working too taking care of baby if you re too exhausted to do that your baby will suffer you could do night on night off for feeds or split each night by time frame it completely unfair for it to be all on you unfair and unsustainable sleep deprivation sucks but the baby is joint responsibility your husband needs to step up and suck it up and help you my husband and took turns we eff so we also had bottles and he was able to help by doing some feeds he still helped when he went back to work we split it up that he would do the first half of the night and would do the second half so he could get decent chunk of sleep before he had to get up and leave he would just have an extra cup or two of coffee at work unless your husband has physical job where being sleep deprived could get him or coworker killed he has no excuse for making you handle everything the only advice have is to talk to your doctor about how sleep deprivation is affecting you then tell your husband what the doctor says or bring him to the appointment maybe being told by doctor that sleep deprivation makes your ppd worse will get him to start helping really hope you re able to make him see reason because your situation sounds untenable there is no cure except to have help if your husband is refusing to do that talk to him about getting night nurse either he helps you at night or he takes over some of your workload during the day so you can sleep he can expect you to do it all he doesn even help at night and he complaining about not getting enough sleep he refuses to help not even one night week you seem to be handling this better than would that for sure often took night shift with my babies for the first few months so my husband could get sleep for his 10hr work days stay at home under but any time needed break or some extra sleep especially when the babies started taking bottles he gladly covered for me well maybe not at first remember many breakdown and arguments in the middle of the night in those first few sleep deprived months they are hard they require communication and teamwork when it hard to function and even harder to work as team you re just five weeks in the sleep deprivation will take its toll in the coming months if you re doing this all on your own please talk to him this is absolutely not fair or healthy for you are you back to work at weeks other than your husband being butthead sorry you have kid now suck it up could you maybe have night nurse come for couple weeks let you get some much needed rest we ve been flirting with getting one for week pp since haven slept well in month as it is and my eye won stop twitching 36weeks my husband will be home for weeks and doing night feeds but will be post section and want to make sure heal uggh baby is 24 job it is just archaic to think this could be added to your responsibilities and work load with no involvement from dad to me this is not acceptable we have 2018 his life changed too you have to fight for yourself and make sure that you get enough time to sleep and for self care he needs to take over at least two shifts day ideally one in the morning and one at night serve him consequences it is either this or he ll take over household tasks or pay external help stick to it you ca go on like this especially considering your health am sorry but what was he thinking the dad part does not start when the kids can play fetch in the backyard he is dad now good luck and please update so did all the night time feeds and wake ups because my husband just couldn do it he doesn wake up the way wake up we tried alternating nights me doing the weekdays and him doing he weekends but it really suited us that did it with the caveat that got naps on the weekends and went to bed at pm and he had ish hours with the baby completely agree with what everyone else is saying he needs to step up and you both need to figure out what type of schedule would work best would night nurse work for you both you have to get some sleep as well this is insane and not sustainable sleep is not luxury it is an absolutely necessary part of your recovery both from birth and ppd go to your doctor or to the pediatrician and have the doctor explain this very basic concept to your much he totally deserved to be murdered in his sleep am so sorry that you are going through this also agree with those who have said that night nurse is in order especially if you think it at all possible financially then just do it he gets to make unilateral decisions about who gets to sleep you get to make unilateral decisions about hiring night nurse husband needs to pull his weight doesn matter he works out of the house parenting is separate from work and doing one does exclude doing the other you two need to come up with plan you both find fair handled all the night wake ups and basically all feeds for baby girl my husband works construction so heavy machinery currently on cliff early mornings and the like made sleep more of safety thing in my head here what worked for us baby girl slept in our room for the first weeks husband slept in the guest room if he did want to be disturbed husband was in charge of meals including mine he kept the fridge stocked with protein shakes for breakfast easy snacks and ordered me in or brought me food for lunch and or dinner if not would have remembered to eat when he got home from work got me time either power nap or shower something to make me feel human as she began bottle my naps got longer and husband does feed try to get baby on schedule moms on call worked great for us no cio to just have an idea of when baby should sleep months and she sleeps 11 hours night do make it competition you will do more baby things he will do more work things you will both be jealous both be exhausted both be stressed turn in be for any decent stretch of time good luck you really should not be back to work yet maternity leave is 12 weeks for reason and the fact that babies do sleep through the night yet is huge part of it your husband if he cares for your mental health and well being he needs to let you sleep when told my dr thought had ppd he looked at my hubby and told him he needed to start letting me sleep more and let me tell you it was night and day difference just getting couple hours of uninterrupted sleep at night helped sooooo much my son usually woke every 30 mins to hour day and night for his while first amp self care are the priorities during the day can not imagine working at 5w pp physically while recovering and can not imagine trying to work and take care of newborn my heart really breaks for you and your husband is being ridiculous what found helped me was to go to bed when the baby would go to bed if your husband is up later than your baby then he could should do any of the feeds wakeups between the time you go to bed and the time he goes to bed for the morning you could doze with your baby in bed from that 6am feed until you have to get up for the day also pumping is not easy it is being able to rotate and hand off tasks throughout the day stop the housework do the absolute bare minimum not really as spiteful jab at him but more for your own sanity got enough clothes to get through five days only do laundry on the weekends when you can hand the baby back and forth and work together and do bother folding anything that does absolutely need it if that motivates him to do they are surprisingly inexpensive and do *amazing* work quickly if husband ca do nighttime wake ups then he can tidy up the house when he gets home from work no more cooking daily dinners either do mealprep weekends when he there to help or learn to live on pizza and cereal for little while this is going to be so bad forever so for now you need to just cut to the bare necessities and take care of you and your baby you can start vacuuming the stairs again when the baby starts sleeping more take advantage of your naps know that pumping and working ca necessarily wait but see if you can work out pattern ve been using the glow baby app for year and half for this the community stuff is crap but the pattern tracker is wonderfully helpful to know when and for how long can expect baby to eat sleep poop obviously at much further stage where stretches between sleeps are longer but know have four hours in the morning to work and play then take nap with him for anywhere from 45 minutes to hours then we eat lunch and play for bit work for more hours take another nap and then start cooking dinner dinner and bedtime routine put him to bed around and then work for another hours or so and get myself to bed around 12 so sleep about five hours at night and anywhere from two to four hours during the day usually around three could theoretically cut the naps and go to bed when he does then just work while he naps but need recharge after few hours of constant work and baby duty would much rather have those three hours of focused work without distractions at night and then take those recharger naps during the day your windows will definitely be shorter and more sporadic but once you ve been tracking it for while it helps your sanity and you ll start to form an idea of what your day will look like instead of just think just changed diaper is he crying because he hungry or tired now if he wants you to take the morning shifts fine he needs to take the evening shift have him take care of bedtime so you can take little nap in the evening before you have to do the first night waking have super frank discussion with him it sounds like you re already very comfortable with that explain to him that while he does have to get up and go out of the house and do work for eight hours you *literally never* get break break down your day and explain to him exactly what you do hour by hour again having the chart from glow baby would be nice visual definitely used this to give my husband wake up call in the early days still remember the day changed 29 diapers he works with you so he should have good idea of how much work you re putting in but you re *also* taking care of the baby at the same time *and* keeping the house together he may be working an hour day but you re working *21 hours day make him agree on schedule for when you can make up some of the difference especially if you have ppd that is seriously dangerous situation and he needs to understand that ppd is not something to mess with so tldr how made it work during that time stop cleaning the house unless totally necessary eat frozen dinners or takeout get an app or scheduler or something to track patterns find the patterns your baby falls into and plan your own time loosely around that schedule daddy time daddy time is important not only for their bonding relationship and love and whatnot but it definitely important for mom health both mental and physical if he works he can take to chill out after work you can eat dinner and then he can take 6:30 or something like that so he does feel like you re just dumping the baby in his arms as soon as he gets home but you still get your own time to yourself for me since my husband works so much later and do have sympathy for his 55 60 hour weeks daddy time is just weekend mornings he wakes up early anyways so saturday and sunday he takes the first wakeup until the first nap time that means that get to go back to sleep for hours in the morning nurse before nap and then go *back* to sleep for my nap it glorious and absolutely makes huge difference good luck hope you are able to work out something sustainable for your growing family soon the
